abstract.text: The content contains a value of the resource.
Adds a new commit with content
. This is like setting the content to
Note that this does not remove the fork, and the fork does still have commits. However, the value of the
most recent commit will be
, to indicate the absence of a resource.
(This construction is sometimes referred to as a “tombstone”. It is a commit that indicates
that something has been removed.)
Convenience for creating simple forked resource for in-memory use.
Create an in-memory ForkedResource with the given forks, and initial value.
The initial value is optional. If not provided, the main fork will be empty.
The setup ensures that all forks are synced up with the initial value, which is different to
the default behavior when you first create a ForkedResource. (In a forked resource,
a new fork is initially empty, and may not be in sync with the main fork until merged.)
Returns the most recent (current) commit of the
Will return the resource, if there is one available, and
otherwise.
Returns a Boolean value indicating whether two values are not equal.
Retrieve the localized description for this error.
If needed, the repo can store data persistently at this point (or do nothing)
Remove a commit for a given version from the fork. If the version is
not found, an error is thrown.
Returns the most recent (current) version of the
Delete an existing fork. Throws if it isn’t present.
No action was taken. The two forks were already at the same version.
Initialize with no persistence
Returns a partial range up to, and including, its upper bound.
Returns a Boolean value indicating whether two values are not equal.
Learn about different strategies for merging forked data.
Merges other forks into main, and then main into the target fork, so it has up-to-date data from all other forks.
You can pass in
if you want to merge all other forks into
The forks in the repository, including .main, in no particular order.
Brings main and the other fork to the same version by first merging from
the other fork into main, and then merging from main into the other fork (fast forward).
This particular overload handles merges of
resources.
To sync up all forks, just pass all forks to this func, including .main. The main fork is ignored
when merging.
Big bang version of every ForkedResource. Effectively, it is ancient history.
Also used as the initial value of any newly created branch
The version when the copy of the resource was committed.
Create a new fork.Will throw if a fork with the same name already exists.
Returns whether main has commits that haven’t been merged into the fork yet.
Persists any pending changes in the underlying repository to permanent storage
Loads repo from storage, if this is supported. Otherwise, does nothing.
Returns a Boolean value indicating whether the value of the first argument
is greater than or equal to that of the second argument.
By default, resource content is treated as not being equal if we can’t test it.
Whether the fork is protected from deletion. Only
the main fork has this protection for now.
Returns a Boolean value indicating whether two values are not equal.
The only fork created by default. All other forkes
can be merged with the main, but not directly with
each other.. It acts as the central hub of the
wheel of forks.
Merges from one fork into the main fork. May perform a 3-way merge.
A
is returned to indicate the type of merge that took place.
After this operation, the main fork may be updated. The version of the other fork will be unchanged.
Note that this may change the commits stored in unrelated forks, in order to preserve common ancestors.
This particular overload handles merges of
resources.
Update the contents of a fork with a new resource value. Will create a commit, and return the
The difference between a restart and an update, is that the resource passed is assumed to be the common
ancestor of the fork with .main. Sometimes you can’t achieve something through merging, and this gives
an override. In general, it should not be needed much, but is handy when in some instances.
Only use this if you know that the value of the resource precedes the value in .main, such that it
is eligble to be a common ancestor. If the value in .main is actually older, doing this will undo any changes in .main.
You can’t restart the .main fork.
Brings main and the other fork to the same version by first merging from
the other fork into main, and then merging from main into the other fork (fast forward).
This particular overload handles merges of
resources.
To sync up all forks, just pass all forks to this func, including .main. The main fork is ignored
when merging.
Returns a Boolean value indicating whether two values are not equal.
Errors that can arise when  using
The action taken when two forks are merged.
Merges all forks so they are all at the same version. This involves merging all forks into the main fork
first, and then merging the main fork into all other forks.
A wrapper to hold the resource. This allows for the resource to be
absent in a fork, similar to using
The most recent (current) version of the main fork.
The two forks had both changed since the common ancestor version.
They were merged to produce a new value for the destination fork.
Whether the fork and main fork are at the same version or not.
An atomic repository is one that gets loaded completely into memory.
If the
it contains conforms to
, the
is
also
, and can be converted to a serialized form and saved as a file.
Saving and loading are atomic, that is, the whole repository is loaded from file, and the whole
file is written to disk.
This is storage for the
. It could
be persisted on disk, or just kept in memory.
This type does not understand any of the mechanisms of forking
and merging. That is all handled by the
, which also
ensures correct multi-threading behavior.
Classes conforming to this type simply have to setup a storage
mechanism, and handle the requests, keeping commits assigned to forks.
Creates and returns an AsyncStream which provides notifications of all changes to any fork
in the repository. The stream will continue until cancelled or until the ForkedResource
is deallocated.
All versions stored in a given fork. There will usually be 0, 1 or 2,
though there may be temporaily more.
Note that this is just the versions stored for the fork. The interpretation
of the stored versions is handled by the
. For example,
if there are no versions in the fork of the repo, the
will assume it is at the same version as stored in the main fork.
Initialize a fork with a given unique name.
Removes all content from all branches, resetting to the initial state.
It does not remove the existing branches, but removes their content.
Returns a partial range extending upward from a lower bound.
Merges other forks into main, and then main into the target fork, so it has up-to-date data from all other forks.
You can pass in
if you want to merge all other forks into
This particular overload handles merges of
resources.
The content is not present. Perhaps it has not been added yet,
or it may have been removed.
Whether fork has commits not yet merged into main.
Returns a half-open range that contains its lower bound but not its upper
bound.
Returns a Boolean value indicating whether the value of the first argument
is less than or equal to that of the second argument.
Merges from the main fork into another fork. May perform a 3-way merge.
A
is returned to indicate the type of merge that took place.
After this operation, the fork may be updated, with the version of the main fork unchanged.
This particular overload handles merges of non-
resources.
The destination fork is behind, and it has no new commits itself.
So the destination fork version was simply made equal to the newer fork version.
This is known as a “fast forward”.
Creates a fork providing an initial commit to populate it with.
Throws if the fork is already present.
If you want to perform a series of calls as a single transaction,
preventing other threads from changing anything between calls,
use this to group the transaction of calls. Note that reentrance of this
method from the same thread will lead to deadlock. It is best not to
execute long running code in the block, because all other interactions
with the
will block waiting.
Merges all forks so they are all at the same version. This involves merging all forks into the main fork
first, and then merging the main fork into all other forks.
This particular overload handles merges of
resources.
Merges from one fork into the main fork. May perform a 3-way merge.
A
is returned to indicate the type of merge that took place.
After this operation, the main fork may be updated. The version of the other fork will be unchanged.
Note that this may change the commits stored in unrelated forks, in order to preserve common ancestors.
This particular overload handles merges of non-
resources.
Returns a closed range that contains both of its bounds.
This manages forks of a resource. It facilitiates concurrent changes to a single resource, and
provides a systematic approach for merging changes, with support for 3-way merging.
A  type representing a named fork.
Returns the common ancestor commit for a given fork with the main fork.
A commit comprises of content, which is usually a value of the stored resource,
together with a
Same as calling
Convenience for creating simple forked resource for in-memory use.
Create an in-memory ForkedResource with the given fork names, and initial value.
The setup ensures that all forks are synced up with the initial value — if there is one —
which is different to the default behavior when you first create a ForkedResource. (In a forked resource,
a new fork is initially empty, and may not be in sync with the main fork until merged.)
Learn how to use Forked to manage shared data in your Swift applications.
Returns the current content of the fork
The content stored in the commit, usually a copy of the resource.
Learn how to use ForkedCloudKit for data synchronization.
Whether a fork exists in the
Initialize the
with a repository. If the repository is new,
and has no main fork, one will be added with an initial commit.
Used to chronologically order file versions. It is a standard lamport count.
Returns a Boolean value indicating whether two values are not equal.
A framework for handling shared data with confidence in Swift.
The resource is Equatable, so test explicitly for equality.
Returns a partial range up to, but not including, its upper bound.
Update the contents of a fork with a new resource value. Will create a commit, and return the
Get the content from the repo with the version passed. If not found,
it will throw an error.
All forks in the resource, including the main fork, in no particular order
Store a version of the resource in a fork. The fork must exist, and the
version must not already be in the fork, otherwise an error is thrown.
Merges from the main fork into another fork. May perform a 3-way merge.
A
is returned to indicate the type of merge that took place.
After this operation, the fork may be updated, with the version of the main fork unchanged.
This particular overload handles merges of
resources.
Returns a Boolean value indicating whether two values are not equal.
The repository used to store data for the forked resource.
The forked resource takes complete ownership of this. You should not
use the repository from outside the
object. Doing so
may lead to threading errors or logic bugs.
Returns a Boolean value indicating whether the value of the first argument
is greater than that of the second argument.
Delete an existing fork. If the fork does not exist, it will throw.
Persist using Codable
Increase the timestamp by 1
The name of the fork
